member.name: T:Topten.RichTextKit.Bidi
member.summary: Implementation of Unicode Bidirection Algorithm (UAX #9) https://unicode.org/reports/tr9/
member.remarks:
The Bidi algorithm uses a number of memory arrays for resolved types, level information, bracket types, x9 removal maps and more...
This implementation of the Bidi algorithm has been designed to reduce memory pressure on the GC by re-using the same work buffers, so instances of this class should be re-used as much as possible.

member.summary: Used to return caret positioning information from the method.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.CaretInfo.CodePointIndex
member.summary: Returns the index of the code point that this caret info refers to.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.CaretInfo.LineIndex
member.summary: Returns the line number that contains the caret

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.CaretInfo.CaretXCoord
member.summary: The X-coordinate where the caret should be displayed for this code point.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.CaretInfo.CaretRectangle
member.summary: A rectangle describing where the caret should be drawn, relative to the top-left corner of the text block. The caret should be drawn from the returned rectangle's top-right to bottom-left.
member.remarks:
This will be based on the *previous* character on this line (or the same character if this is first character in the line).
Usually this will be a zero-width rectangle describing the x, top and bottom coordinates of where the caret should be drawn. The width of the drawn caret isn't provided and should be determined by the client.
When the caret is immediately following an italic character, the returned rectangle will be sloped to the right and should be drawn from the top-right coordinate to the bottom-left coordinate.
If you don't want to draw a sloped caret for italics, use the top and bottom coordinates of the returned rectangle and get the x-coordinate from the property.

member.name: T:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult
member.summary: Used to return hit test information from the method.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult.OverLine
member.summary: The zero based index of the line number the y-coordinate is directly over, or -1 if the y-coordinate is before the first line, or after the last line.
member.remarks: The x-coordinate isn't used in calculating this value and the left/right limits aren't checked.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult.ClosestLine
member.summary: The zero based index of the closest line to the passed y-coordinate.
member.remarks: If the point is directly over a line this value will be the same as the property. If the point is before the first line, this property will be 0. If the point is after the last line this value will be the index of the last line.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult.OverCodePointIndex
member.summary: The code point index of the first code point in the cluster that the point is actually over, or -1 if not over a cluster.

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult.ClosestCodePointIndex
member.summary: The code point index of the first code point in the cluster that the point is closest to.
member.remarks:
If the point is over a cluster, the returned code point index will vary depending whether the point is in the left or right half of the cluster and the text direction of that cluster.
This value represents the code point index that the caret should be moved to if the user clicked the mouse at this position. To determine the co-ordinates and shape of the caret, see [Caret Information](/caret).

member.name: F:Topten.RichTextKit.HitTestResult.AltCaretPosition
member.summary: Indicates that the point is closest to the alternate caret position of ClosestCodePointIndex.
member.remarks: This property indicates if the tested point is beyond the end of a word wrapped line and not at the start of the following line.

member.name: T:Topten.RichTextKit.StyleManager
member.summary: Helper class for managing RichTextKit styles.
member.remarks:
The StyleManager can be used to simplify the creation of styles by maintaining a current style that incremental changes can be made to.
eg: turn bold on, underline off, change font family etc...
The StyleManager also implements an internal stack to simplify applying a particular style and then popping back to the previous style.

member.name: M:Topten.RichTextKit.TextBlock.AddEllipsis
member.summary: Appends an ellipsis to this text block
member.remarks:
This method checks if the text block has already been truncated and if not appends an ellipsis without changing the measured vertical layout of the text block. The ellipsis only remains in effect until the block's layout is recalculated.
The text block must have at least one line. If the block contains no text, then use AddText("\n", style) to create a single line with an attached style but no text.
The intended purpose of this is to included an ellipsis on this text block when a following text block doesn't fit.

member.name: M:Topten.RichTextKit.TextBlock.ResetPooledMemory
member.summary: Resets and internal object and memory pools.
member.remarks:
For performance reasons and to reduce pressure on the garbage collector, RichTextKit maintains several internal per-thread memory and object pools.
If you create a very large text block, these pools will be enlarged to cope with content of larger text blocks.
This method can be used to reset those pools to reclaim the extra memory they consumed.
In general you can ignore this method, unless you know you're working with very large text blocks (which you shouldn't be anyway, since a text block is only supposed to be a single paragraph). ///
